page.title: 16INTERVIEW WITH AN OLD PERSON
page.content: In the old days (1930's) people did not have as much money as we do today. Mr.Drayson said that you could buy 10 sweets for a penny (old pence) and a quarter of gobstoppers would have only cost about 3d. They said that their mothers bought their food in the village shops and hardly ever went to Dover. If they did go to the town it would have cost them 6d return on the old bus (a converted van driven twice a week to Dover by Mr.Wellard). The houses in the village at that time were far fewer and the number of people in the village was about 800 (there are about 2000 today). When asked if they preferred life when they were young they both said no! They enjoy living in St.Margaret's today.
